title: Did the ancient Greeks think of themselves as 'Greeks', or did they only think of themselves as 'Athenians', 'Spartans', 'Corinthians', etc.? - Quora

response.answer_text: Simple answer: Both. Ancient Greeks thought of themselves as Athenian, Macedonian, Syracusian, Theban, Ionian, etc., as a mater of Nationality - e.g. my country is the city and surrounding areas of Athens. In parallel, Ancient Greeks thought of themselves as Greek (Hellene/Helinas/Έλληνας) as a mater of Ethnicity. An example would be a Greek living in the United States. He/she may be an American by nationality, but ethnically is Greek. If you’re interested in learning more about this topic (which has shades of complexity), there is a fantastic book by the Harvard Center for Hellenic Studies: Ancient Perceptions of Greek Ethnicity

I am sure you did not read Homer’s Odyssey, for…had you read it will come across many passages that when he refers to the Greeks collectively he often uses the words <<Danae>> or <<PanHellens>>. We all know that Hommer’s Odyssey describes the Trojan war fought many thousands of years ago between the Greeks and Trojans at the time when Mycenae was at the pick of their power. long before Athens was established as the supreme city state in the Hellenic world. On individual terms, he refers to them by their tribal name or their place of origins such as <<Argites>> meaning the people from Argos or Melelaos of Sparta, Odysseus of Ithaca. When referencing to the followers of Achilles, par examples he refers to them as the <<mirmidons>> this is not derived by their origin but from their tribal name. What we need to have in mind is that the Greeks of antiquity were tribal people whose loyalty was to their city and their King and often fought each other mainly over land issues but at the same time knew that all were the same nation, had the same customs and traditions and although spoke different dialects it eas the same Greek language. This exists even to our days. The Cypriots par example speak in their own (Cypriot) dialect of the Greek language same for the Cretans, the Pontious (people from Pontus, the area of the black sea) the Grecians ( south Italy) etc.

The ancient Greeks were aware of their tribal identity (phyle, phara, phratria) their larger tribal/linguistic one (Doric, Aeolic, Arcado-Cypriot, Ionic-Attic) as well as their local/geographic identity “Athenian,” “Spartan” (Laconian) Corinthian, Macedonian, Cretan ect. Aside from that they were all aware of their common identity as Hellenes. Hellenes were defined as “being of the same stock and same speech, worshiping the same gods and keeping the same customs.” So yes, they saw their identity on many different levels both local, regional and for lack of a better term national.

the answer is very simple if you take into consideration the size of the known world and its population back then. They considered themselves Athenians, Spartans etc as much as today Colombians, Chileans, mexicans etc consider themselves as such, but they thought themselves as hellenes just as Colombians, Chileans, Mexicans etc today consider themselves latinoamericanos. there is a strong bond, they know each other's cultures well, etc. And sometimes they do fight. But in the end they are brothers.

They were thinking themselves as belonging to the same genre sharing common language (although they spoke distinctly different dialects / versions of it), common religion, common history and common ethos at least vis a vis to the people who did not belong to the genre. They considered themselves ‘Hellenes’ but the also had deep local identities which they treasured. Alexander the Great after his first major triumph in the battlefields against Perseans dedicated the gifts in the name of all the Hellenes who were participating in the campaign.

They thought that they were Athenians, Spartans, Corinthias, Macedonias, Trojans, etc but also Greek. The same thing applies to the modern Greeks but at less extend. I would like also like to correct Costas in regards to the Trojans. They were Greeks. The believe on the same gods, had the same language and considered themselves Greeks. Both sides Danaes and Trojans had allies that were not Greeks and spoke different language. According to Virgil’s Aeneid the fugitive Trojans changed the language from Greek to the local Latin after the men (they have already abandoned their wifes in Sicily) mixed with the Latins in the vicinity of Rome. Due to this heritage Romans could compete to the Olympic games.

Ancient Greece was a civilization rather than a nation as we define the term today. Athenians, Spartans, Macedonian, Thebans etc all had a strong tribal identity and all felt they belonged to their city or kingdom. At the same time, they were all Hellenes, as defined by common language, religion, culture etc. All's Hellenes participated in the Olympic games, which was a Greek only event.
Both. They thought of themselves enough as ‘Greeks’ to organize the Olympics and respect Delphi. Many Greeks looked down on Macedonia and Pyrius so there was a little ‘snobbery’ in the polity.

It depends on the period. In homeric times, we do not know, perhaps the greeks mentionned there were a small tribe in Achilles s camp but a nation to the listeners. We do not know. In classical times, culminating in the Persian wars, and also the Alexander era, much later, yes. Now the Peloponnesian War was a civil war.

All of the above, except of Greeks. They considered themselves as Hellenes who were very proud and independent city-states, Athens, Sparta, Corinth, Rhodes, Macedonia, etc. Greek and Greece came later by the Romans but it also has its origin in the Hellenic tradition. All, Athenians and the rest were very proud of their common Hellenic ancestry.

They considered themselves as Greeks (Hellenes) as well. There were oaths from all cities to protect holly areas like Dodoni or Delphi, so they had the conscience that they belonged in the same nation.
